title: Crown's high-roller business slumps 46pc
text:
Allegations of links between criminal organisations and the junket operators who bring wealthy Asian gamblers to Crown Resorts ’s Australian casinos appear to have hit the company's trading performance, with turnover in its VIP business plunging 46 per cent in the early months of the 2020 financial year.

VIP program turnover play between July 1 and October 20 fell 46 per cent "reflecting the difficult trading conditions in the international VIP market", executive chairman John Alexander told the annual general meeting in Melbourne on Thursday.

But Crown's rival, The Star Entertainment Group, which runs casinos in Sydney, Brisbane and the Gold Coast, suffered no such problems, reporting that normalised revenue from VIP play, which removes the impact of luck during any one period, rose between July 1 and October 21, although a lucky streak for punters would hit the VIP division's statutory earnings.

There were better signs from Crown's domestic business, with main gaming floor revenue excluding VIP play climbing 2 per cent in the first few months of the year.

The Star said normalised revenue from local punters rose 1.5 per cent between July 1 and October 21, compared with the year-earlier period.

The Star said it expects normalised earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation in the six months ending December 31 will total $300 million - $310 million, above last year's result of $297 million.
description: Crown said its high-roller program turnover has fallen 46 per cent 'reflecting the difficult trading conditions in the international VIP market'.
